Dosage:
Zao jia (Fructus): Often used in powder form, 1–1.5 g daily. For decoction: 1.5–5 g. Also for external use.

Zao jiao ci (Spina): 0.5–2.0 g daily.
Samples of Formulae:
For constipation or mild intestine obstruction: Zao Jiao Ci (Chinese honey locust thorn) 12 g, Xi Xin (Asarum) 12 g; grind into powder, mix with Honey 120 g; make into suppository and insert into anus while warm. [1]

External method for postpartum milk accumulation (初產婦積乳): Wrap the powder of the herb in gauze; moisten the outer layer with 75% alcohol; insert into the nostril.
Contraindications: Do not overdose; large amounts can induce vomiting and diarrhea. Do not use during pregnancy, or in cases of qixu (qi deficiency), yinxu (yin deficiency), or hemoptysis. Due to its very strong acrid-dispersing and penetrating nature, it is suitable for stubborn phlegm excess patterns in robust individuals.
Notes:
Imitated products identification (zao jiao ci): Zao jiao ci are thorns from Gleditsia sinensis Lam. A complete intact piece is cone-shaped with a main thorn and 1–2 side thorns. The main thorn is about 3–15 cm long (or slightly longer) with a diameter of 0.3–1.2 cm. Side thorns are 1–6 cm long, spiraling around the branches and forming a 60–80° angle with the main thorn; they gradually get thinner upward. Surfaces are brown to dark brown; tips are sharp, mostly dark red with fine vertical lines; they are light in weight and hard (not easily broken). Broken or cut surfaces show yellowish white wood under the surface; the pith is not dense and light reddish brown. Odorless and bland in taste.

Adulterants and quality issues (zao jiao ci): Past main substitutes include thorny branches of Ziziphus jujuba Mill., Sophora japonica L., Rosa multiflora Thunb., Vitex negundo L. var. heterophylla (Franch) Rehd., Paliurus ramosissimus Poir., and Rubus coreanus; most commonly mixed in are branches of Gleditsia melanacantha. A more recent fake product is Gleditsia heterophylla Bunge. Quality issues are serious, including mixing in large amounts of dry branches without thorns and nonstandard processing and slicing. [2]

Hemoptysis: The expelling of blood or of blood-streaked sputum from the larynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs.

Flavonoid and phenolic constituents in seeds: apigenin (apigenin aglycone), chlorogenic acid, rutin.

Name: jiang huang
Other name: huang si yu jin (yu jin is Curcuma aromatica Salisb. It is not jiang huang, Curcuma longa)
chun yu jin (yu jin is Curcuma aromatica Salisb. It is not jiang huang, Curcuma longa)

Maladies Treated: Chest and abdomen pain caused by blood stasis
Medical Function: Improves circulation of blood and qi.
Promotes flow of menses and relieves pain.
Anti-coagulation of platelets; inhibits platelet aggregation and anti-thrombus formation.
Protects cardiac muscle from lack of oxygen (ischemic injury).
Inhibits replication of HBV (hepatitis B virus).
Enhances fibrinolysis (the process that breaks down fibrin (fibrous proteins), such as those that protect tumors from the immune system).
Helps intestinal peristalsis (intestinal movements that help evacuation).
Curcumin inhibits prosurvival pathways in chronic lymphocytic leukemia B cells and, combined with green tea extract epigallocatechin-3 gallate (EGCG), may overcome their stromal protection. [1]
Inhibits forming of fibrosis in the lungs of cystic fibrosis patients.
Contraindications:
Prolonged large dosage may irritate the gastric mucosa and cause stomach ulcer.
Contraindicated if blood deficient but without qi stagnation and blood stasis.
Research:
Curcumin inhibits prosurvival pathways in chronic lymphocytic leukemia B cells; combined with green tea extract epigallocatechin-3 gallate (EGCG) may overcome stromal protection. [1]

In mice, a significant fall in the WBC and RBC levels was observed in Curcuma longa (jiang huang)-treated animals compared to controls. [2]

Reporting in the Dec. 7, 2004, online edition of the Journal of Biological Chemistry, a research team determined curcumin is more effective in inhibiting formation of the protein fragments than many other drugs being tested as Alzheimer's treatments. Amyloid plaque (b-amyloid) is an abnormal aggregation of protein fragments that leads to memory decline in Alzheimer's disease. A study from University of California, Los Angeles, using mice indicated turmeric not only prevents accumulation of plaques in those with degenerative brain disease but can also stop plaque development at the first stage. The result was published in a biochemistry journal.

Modern research links provided: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15974909 and http://www.studa.net/yaoxue/080522/11150373.html (Chinese with English abstract).
